citation.abstract: By depicting who eats whom, food webs offer descriptions of how groupings in nature (typically species or populations) are linked to each other. For asking questions on how food webs are built and work, we need descriptions of food webs at different levels of resolution. DNA techniques provide opportunities for highly resolved webs. In this paper, we offer an exposé of how DNA-based techniques, and DNA barcodes in particular, have recently been used to construct food web structure in both terrestrial and aquatic systems. We highlight how such techniques can be applied to simultaneously improve the taxonomic resolution of the nodes of the web (i.e., the species), and the links between them (i.e., who eats whom). We end by proposing how DNA barcodes and DNA information may allow new approaches to the construction of larger interaction webs, and overcome some hurdles to achieving adequate sample size. Most importantly, we propose that the joint adoption and development of these techniques may serve to unite approaches to food web studies in aquatic and terrestrial systems-revealing the extent to which food webs in these environments are structured similarly to or differently from each other, and how they are linked by dispersal.
citation.title: The use of DNA barcodes in food web construction – terrestrial and aquatic ecologists unite!

author.name: NCL Network Ecology

author.name: Darren Evans
author.description: Reader in Ecology and Conservation at Newcastle University researching ecological networks/food-webs. Follow my group @NCLNEG

author.name: Ian King
author.description: Nematologist by training. Recently, postdoc, Centre for Biodiversity Genomics, U Guelph, studying eDNA. Now, Research Scientist with Canadian federal government

author.name: Anna Traveset
author.description: Ecologist interested in species interactions and how they are disrupted by different drivers of global change plus island lover @IMEDEA_UIB_CSIC #biodiversity

author.description: Ecologist at @LeibnizIGB meandering between food webs, animal behavior, & conservation biology | tweets trilingual mainly EN, at times DE or ES | views are mine

author.description: Dean, Faculty of Science @RyersonU | Cell Biologist | Advocate of #equity #diversity #inclusivity #STEM #scicomm | WXN Top 100 Women in Canada 2016
